HOPKINS WINS STATE CHAMPIONSHIP

BRICKLEY'S ACHIEVEMENT A
RECORD IN HOPKINS FOOTBALL

Record Crowd Sees 'Varsity Down Aggies and Win Championship
of State—Hoffman's Goal from Field Only Score of
Game—Hopkins Team Plays Like Machine.

Harvard Star, Fighting Down Adverse
Conditions, Won His Way by Sheer
Personality—His Success with the
Team Phenomenal —Whether
He Will Stay Not Known.

Hopkins defeated the Aggies, 3 to o.
In a few words, this tells the story of the long-awaited and muchdiscussed football game that was played at Homewood on Thanksgiving
Day before the greatest crowd in Homewood's history; where victory
brought to Hopkins the undisputed college championship of the State of
Maryland—a'game that was played by one of the greatest elevens that ever
represented the Black and Blue, an eleven whose success this season
was largely due to the efforts of Hopkins' master coach, Charles Brickley.
The lone score of the game came shortly after the opening of the
fourth quarter, when Bobby Hoffman, standing on the 20-yard line, dropkicked the pigskin squarely between the goal posts. This kick, besides
winning the game, gave Hopkins the first victory over the Aggies
since 1911.
The team played as it should: as a team and not as individuals. The
defense was impregnable, and their attack, although pitted against a line

By GEO. EDWIN DORSEY

The magnificent victory of the
football team on Thanksgiving
Day, which sent what was perhaps
the most formidable aggregation
that has ever represented any college in Maryland down to defeat
and at last gave to Johns Hopkins
the premier position in the State
in football that it has held in the
other branches of sport for some
time, completed what was probably
the most crucial year of football
that the University has ever had.
While it is always thought at the
time that every year is crucial in
football, a moment's consideration
will show in how many respects
1915 was especially so for Johns
Hopkins. At the conclusion of the
1914 season the team had won two
games, tied one and lost five. The
defeats all came in a row, with
the exception of the tie with Gettysburg. .In addition, one of the players was so severely injured in one
of the games that he died later.
The crowds on the whole were fair,
considering the performance of the
team. But after that deadly St.
John's affair, when, before next
to the largest crowd that has ever
seen a Hopkins-St. John's game,
the team was defeated 34 to 13,
there was a general feeling of peSsimism regarding football possibilities at the University, and the public was disgusted.
It made no difference when we
pleaded that laboratories made it
practically impossible for the team
to get any daylight practice; that
for two weeks before the biggest
game of the year no forward passes
could be attempted on account of
the ball's passing out of the zone
of the acetylene lights; that we had
no larger a student body to draw
from than several of the other colleges in the State, which were not
hampered for time to practice. We
simply had a consistently-losing
football team, and hence any pretensions of the University in this field
were a joke.
Keenly cognizant of all this, a
number of the alumni and members of the Athletic Board had a
meeting to face the facts. Alost of
these (myself among the number)
were in favor of either abolishing
football altogether or of removing
the almost insuperable obstacles
which were in the way of our turning out creditable football teams.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 29, 1915.

DEBATERS PICK OUT SUBJECTS CHAUCERIAN LECTURES ISSUED COTILLON SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED
Topics for Argument in Triangular League
Selected—New System Proposed by
North Carolina Rejected.

At a meeting of the Debating
Council. last Wednesday a request
of the University of North Caroline to alter the system of the triangular league was considered and
.reliised, and the ,choice of a subject to submit to the other two
members -of the league was undertaken.
The request of the University of
North Carolina was that the system of debate under which Virginia, North Carolina and Hopkins
have held their debates in the past
be so altered that instead of both of
the teams of each university debating away from home, one team of
each university should meet its opponent upon its home ground.
The Council was taken somewhat
unawares by this request, as there
had been no inkling of it before the
letter sent by North Carolina was
received, and as the system in the
past had been considered to work
with remarkable success. The proposed change was taken up as the
first business of the meeting, and,
after some discussion, it was decided that a letter should be sent
to the University of North Carolina stating that Hopkins preferred
debating under the old arrangements.
The Council, in taking this action, decided that whatever might
be the advantages of one team debating at its own university, the
present system, under which- each
team debates in foreign territory,
has proved to be so exceedingly
satisfactory that it should not be
superseded. Under the present system, the conditions under which the
teams debate are made as equal as
is possible, while under the proposed system one team would always have the advantages of familiarity. with the surroundings and the
support of the audience. The debates of the past have always drawn
large crowds, even though the local
university was not represented, and
the ,system itself has been thought
to be so successful as to be given
in full in the last Inter-collegiate
Debate Book.
After action had been taken upon
this matter, the subject which Hopkins is to propose to the other two
members of the league was considered. The committee appointed
to submit a list of subjects, consisting of A. A. Weech (chairman), T.
J. Tingley and R. Oppenheimer,
made a report prdposing about
eight subjects for consideration by
the Council. After some discussion, these subjects were narrowed
down to three: The unicameral system in State governments, the State
budget, and the advisability of the
annexation of Nicaragua by the
United States.
These subjects have not as yet
been definitely worded, and it is
indeed possible that none of them

Series Given by Professor Kittredge at
Hopkins Done into Book Form—Author Thanks Johns Hopkins
for Co-operation.

The six lectures delivered upon
Chaucer by Prof. George L. Kittredge, of Harvard University, at
Johns Hopkins in 1914, as the
Turnbull lectures of that year, have
been published in book form.
As will be remembered, this series
of lectures was, at the time, considered one of the best ever given under the Foundation. Professor Kittredge is one of the best Chaucerian
authorities in the country, and the
publication of these lectures have
been looked forward to with much
interest by all Chaucerian scholars.
The lectures have been transposed
to book form with very few
changes. The introduction of the
book reads as follows:
"The six lectures that comprise
this volume were delivered at the
Johns Hopkins University in April
and May, 1914, being the nineteenth course of lectures in poetry
in the Percy Turnbull Memorial
Foundation. They are presented as
delivered, except with such slight
emendations as naturally suggest
themselves when one prepares a
manuscript for the press. Since
the plan of the book excludes footnotes, I wish to make the fullest
kind of general acknowledgement
to Chaucerian scholars in both hemispheres for the help which their
published writings have afforded
me. To the founders of the lectureship and to my friends and colleagues in Baltimore, I am deeply
indebted for their cordial expressions of interest and their delightful
hospitality.
"Cambridge, January 22, 1915."
The lectures are arranged in the
book in the exact order in which
they were delivered at Hopkins:
First, there is "The Man and His
Times"; second, "The Book of the
Duchess"; third, "The House of
Fame"; fourth, "Troilus"; fifth,
"The Canterbury Tales"(part one);
and sixth, "The Canterbury Tales"
(part two).
Professor Kittredge has been in
Baltimore several times since he delivered his lectures, several of his
friends being members of the Hopkins faculty. His last public apnearance before the University was
at the inauguration ceremonies last
May, when he was awarded an
honorary degree.

First Dance to Take Place December 4.
Music by Fisher's Orchestra—Expected to Be Great Success.

Friday evening, December 3, will
mark the opening of the Cotillon
Club's activities. A large majority
of the undergraduates, graduates
and alumni are expected to attend
this, the first Hopkins dance of the
season; and the Cotillon Board
hopes this dance will excel all previous ones in attendance and enjoyment.
As in former years, Louie Fisher
will have charge of the music, and
from the time he starts to play for
the first dance at 9 o'clock sharp
until the end, the dancers will have
the benefit of as fine dance music
as can be heard anywhere in the
United States. There will be an intermission at i i o'clock for refreshments, after which the dance will
continue until 12.30.
The Cotillon Board has announced its plans for the rest of
the scholastic year. There will be
a second dance On the evening of
February 4, and the last (lance of
the year will take place on April 29.
The dance is open to the whole
University—graduates, undergraduates, and alumni—and the members of the faculty and their wives
are cordially invited by the Cotillon
Club to be present.
Among those who have been
asked to act as chaperons for the
occasion are the following: Mrs. J.
E. Gilpin, Mrs. F. J. Goodnow,
Mrs. M. P. Brush, Mrs. B. H. Griswold, Jr. Mrs. J. M. Vincent, Mrs.
Caswell '
Grave, Mrs. Watson and
Mrs. Henry Wood.
The treasurer of the Cotillon
Board is very anxious to have
everyone pay up as soon as possible.
There is a charge of $2.50 for undergraduates and graduates for
one cotillon, or $6 for the series of
three dances. The charge for alumni is $1.5o for one dance, or $4 for
the three.
The Cotillon Board, in whose
hands rests the arrangement of all
affairs connected with the dances, is
composed of the following: Charles
H. Tinges, chairman; William H.
Skinner, secretary; Robert G.. Merrick, treasurer; Franklin Cromwell,
Stuart Egerton, A. A. Hardy, William Kendall, Jr., R. W. Woodward.

The annual freshman-sophomore
football game is scheduled to take
place on the afternoon of Saturday,
December 4. This will be the first
direct clash in which the two underclasses will have engaged, and the
outcome of the contest will play a
large part in forming opinion as to
the relative strength of the two
classes.
Although Coach Brickley has
been asked to coach the freshmen,
according to his announcement at
the last mass-meeting he will help
both teams, devoting the most of
his time to whichever team is the
weakest.
Both sophomores and freshmen
have men on the 'Varsity and both
also have a large number of men on
the "scrubs." Hoffman, of course,
is the most prominent man in the
sophomore line-up, but there will
also be Woodward, Cort, Duncan
and Darley, who have been practicing with the 'Varsity the entire
season.
Schmidt is the only freshman
who has played on the first team
throughout the season. However,
Sonneborn, Frock, Stanley, Kirke
and Prince, all members of the Hopkins squad, are all freshmen and
are expected to form the nucleus
of an extremely good team. Moreover, there are several good players
in the Freshman Class who did not
go out for the Hopkins team.
Among these are Allen and Cox,
who played on the City College
eleven last year, and Frisch and
Myer, who played backfield positions for Friends' School.
The freshman team began practice Saturday, November 27. Although many sophomores have been
practicing with the 'Varsity squad,
the regular practice of the lophomore team did not begin until Monday of this week.

The State Championship.

When the football team began
practice upon Homewood Field this
September, they went out with a
definite aim. It was an aim which
-has been held by every one of Hopkins' football teams for the last
decade—the winning of the championship of the State. As the season progressed, and as one victory
after the other was brought home
under the guidance of Coaches
Brickley and Brennick, the hopes
of the University mounted higher
and higher, until, before the St.
John's game, they welt aroused
to fever pitch. Our team realized what the winning of those
last two games meant, and it went
into them with a spirit which has
never been excelled in the history
of Hopkins. With the blowing of
the final whistle last Thursday, that
spirit had proven its power—the
long-coveted championship had been
attained.
That last victory was one of
which the University may well be
proud. Won •over a team which
contested every inch of ground and
which fought as clean and as
straight a game as it is possible to
fight, -it means that our success

is flawless; that, in fact as well as
in title, our team is the best within
the State.
Coming at a time when the longcherished dream of moving to
Homewood is about to be realized,
our victory has a double significance. It not only means that the
team of this year is the champion
of the State; it means also that
Hopkins has now a record to maintain and a reputation up to which
to live.
The crowd which thronged the
stands and field last Thursday is
proof of the increased importance
which is being attached to the contests of the Hopkins team; it is for
us to prove that the team which
won this support is only to be the
forerunner of a long line of teams
which will uphold the standard it
has set.
We cannot place our hopes too
high; it would be useless to predict
that within the next few years Hopkins will have a team which will
rival those of universities with five
and six thousand students. Yet
this much we can say: the team and
the spirit which this season has produced are not a culmination, but a
beginning.
Brickley.

Hopkins is tasting the sweets of
victory, and, in enjoying that victory, it remembers and thanks the
men who made it possible. We owe
the football championship of the
State to the men of the team, to
their fighting spirit, destined to live
long in Hopkins history; we owe it
to the "scrubs" who have given
their best in obscurity that the team
might be the stronger; but, more
than to anyone else, we owe it to one
man—Charles Brickley.
Brickley came to this University
fresh from the laurels of national
honors; he came from a university
twenty times as large as Hopkins,
from a team which was one of the
best that university ever produced.
He came to a university whose
spirit suffered from the undeniable
handicap of the lack of dormitories,
a university where the total number of candidates was not onethird as large as the "scrub" forces
of his old team. Yet, despite these
things, he threw himself into his
work with all the enthusiasm of
which he was capable; he devoted
all of his time and energy to the
building up of a team that has
gloriously proved its worth, and
to the development of a spirit which
marks the beginning of a new University.
He has done more than give
Hopkins a championship team. He
has been more than a coach, and
has done, more than merely fulfill
the requirements of his position. In
every sense of the word, he has
been a Hopkins man.
,THE NEWS-LETTER desires to express its most Sincere hope that
Brickley will be back again next
year to lead our team once more to
triumphant victory. But, whether
'he be here or not, there is not a
man in the University who does

not appreciate the great benefits
which his presence has brought, and
who does not feel personally grateful for what he has done.
BRICKLEY'S ACHIEVEMENT A
RECORD IN HOPKINS FOOTBALL
(Continued from page I)

situation was enlisted and permission was finally given that the men
who were playing football would
be allowed to leave the laboratories
at from 3.30 to 4 o'clock, and these
men would be given every chance
possible to make up their work.
This was not, however, accomplished as easily as it sounds, and it
was only after the faculty saw that
something must be done, that they
were won,over.
With a vague promise that this
might be accomplished, the work
of selecting the coach was undertaken. There were a number of
possibilities, but, of course, out-topping all the rest was Charlie Brickley. It is no betrayal of confidence
to say that he was an expensive
proposition for Johns Hopkins, and
we should not have been able to
secure his services had not the
alumni stepped into the breach and
said that, with the belief that the
faculty would cooperate, to some
extent at least, they would supply
the necessary help.
Under these circumstances Brickley was brought to Hopkins. He
came to us as probably the most
famous college man in America,
having had all of the honors that
could be given him on the football
field, on the baseball field, as a
member of the United States Olympic team, etc. He had everything
to lose, and what looked at the time
like very little to gain, by coming
to Hopkins. He had received letters from former Hopkins football
coaches, telling him what he was
up against at Hopkins. But he
nevertheless decided to come. Had
he not been any more successful
than those who had gone before,
the difficulties at Hopkins would
have received wide-spread notoriety
because of Brickley's fame. Thus
we, in a way, were risking a lot
by bringing a man with Brickley's
reputation to Hopkins. But those
who were responsible for the thing
were confident that it would at least
bring matters to a head—it would
either work or it would be the
reductio ad absurdum,.
And those who would have had
to have borne the brunt of the
whole affair felt more than repaid
when the referee's whistle blew on
Thanksgiving Day and those eleven
tired but victorious men trotted off
They were
Homewood Field.
moved by a feeling of profound
gratification, for they had seen what
Hopkins could do if it got a chance,
and had had the faith, which even
some loyal Hopkins men had lost,
rewarded.
Thus the 1915 football situation
was crucial in that it was a case of
either kill or cure. And, in a way,
it is especially gratifying to all

Hopkins men that the team should
have done so well in 1915, for this
is almost certainly the last year of
the old conditions. With every indication that the University, in all
its branches, will be at Homewood
next year, with entirely new conditions, it was our last chance to
show these, as it seemed at times,
hypercritical Baltimoreans a n d
Marylanders what Johns Hopkins
could do when it got the opportunity. And even the most skeptical were silent after that Thanksgiving Day set-to.
From the above, it is seen that it
is impossible to attribute to any
one source the success of the team.
The faculty perhaps did the most,
theoretically; but, practically, the
men did not get out the way it had
been hoped they would. They had
a most exasperating habit, from
the coaches' standpoint, of being
detained by some long experiment,
and of not getting on the field until
after dark.
And had it not been for the undying determination in the hearts
of men like Brooks, Hoffman, Wilkinson, Leibensperger, Bowers,
Primrose, Fulton, Gorman and the
many others on the squad to wipe
out the old stigma on Hopkins football, and the faithful interest of
Ormond, Barclay, Finney, Martindale and Sachs, who had other alma
maters, no amount of getting out
early or of superior coaching would
have availed, and the closing season
woultd have had a very different
story to tell. One of the characteristics of the team most commented on was its fight and the grim
determination which often turned
what looked like defeat into ultimate victory.
But, without taking any of the
credit from the faculty, or forgetting that it was the fight of the
men which made victory possible, it
is Charlie Brickley, more than any
other one person, who must be
given the credit for achieving the
1915 success. And it must be said
that he had been receiving the
credit that is due him from the
public and students alike, which is
why I mentioned the two other
factors, which are likely to be overlooked in the universal rejoicing.
However, these do not in any way
mar the splendor of the Hopkins
"miracle man."
When he first came to Baltimore
and fully realized what he was up
against, Brickley was profoundly
discouraged. And it was here that
Hank Brennick got in his fine work,
for he took Charlie in hand, and
with a skill rarely equaled led him
out of the "chaos," to use Brickley's own term, in which he found
himself shortly after assuming
charge of the squad. But once
having gotten his feet, there was
no stopping him. He worked
among the medical men and undergraduates alike, and not only did
he get them out, but he kept them
out, which is most important of
all. Never in my experience with

Hoffman, on the first down, shot

crowd became almost frantic with
excitement. To be sure, the first
score of the game was about to be
made.
Hopkins tried two line plunges,
but only gained four yards. Woodward rushed out on the field and replaced Schmidt at guard. He carcied instructions to Bowers to try
a field goal. On the next play,
Bobby sent the pigskin over the
cross-bar for the first and only score
of the game.
The last quarter was Hopkins'.
The Aggies were never dangerous
during the rest of the game. Their
players did not have the same vim
which had characterized them previously. Hopkins had apparently
worn them out.

McCOY HALL CONCERT FEB. 25
Musicians to Hold Home Engagement at
Favorable Time—Men Still Needed
for Both Clubs—Prospects Bright.

The Musical Clubs are now in
full swing, and, from the progress
thus far made, there is every prospect that the season will be as successful as that of any of the Clubs
of previous years.
An unusually large number of
candidates has reported at the Glee
Club rehearsals, and, while it is still
too early to choose the men who are
to have places in the Club, with the
material on hand there should be no
,difficulty in finding enough good
singers for every part. The competition, however, is just beginning
and all candidates who have not yet
registered are urged to do so as
soon as possible.
The old members of the Glee
Club have turned out in full force
and furnish a nucleus around which
the Club is easily reshaping itself.
In addition, several good voices
have been found in the Freshman
Class. The chief difficulty which
confronts the Club is the same difficulty against Which it has been
necessary for all Hopkins clubs to
contend—the majority of the men
are unable to read music, and must
be taught their parts separately.
However, this difficulty can be overcome by patient practice, and every
week, as the men become more fathiliar with the music, better results
are being obtained.
The Glee Club now meets twice
a week—on Tuesday evenings and
on Saturday afternoons. Likewise,
as the season progresses, rehearsals
at the lunch hour will be begun.
This frequent and regular practice
for the Glee Club is comparatively
a new thing at Hopkins, and is already showing results.
The Instrumental Club, while
progressing satisfactorily, is still in
need of men. There is room in
every department of the orchestra
—piano, violins, mandolins, guitars,
'cello, bass-violin, flute and drums.
The Club lost several valuable members last year, and still others, due
to sickness or work, have so far
found it impossible to report at the
rehearsals.
Despite this handicap, however,
the Club is gradually rounding into
shape. The rehearsals take place
Friday evening, as is the custom of
this Club. Due to the failure of the
publishers to send the music which
had been ordered, rehearsals were
begun somewhat later this year than
is usual, but the spirit which all the
men are putting into their practice
has more than made up for the late
start.
While no trips have as yet been
arranged, the managerial staff announces that several are under consideration, and that the season as a
whole is expected to be a busy one.
The McCoy Hall concert has been
booked for February 25, this date
having been temporarily selected so
as not to conflict with the cotillons
or any other University activity.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 29, 1915.
Hopkins Men Will Usher.

A letter has been received from
the Maryland League for National
Defense, asking for twenty-five
Hopkins men to serve as ushers at
the big mass-meeting for national
defense at the Lyric on Saturday,
December 4. Seniors.are preferred,
but it makes little difference, so king
as they are Hopkins men. Each
usher will be given two reserVed
seats.
It is expected that the ushers will
have their "hands full," for the
Lyric will be filled to its maximum
capacity. The principal speaker of
the evening will be the Hon. James
M. Beck, of New York, who is
considered the country's greatest
orator on national defense. The
vice-presidents of the mass-meeting
will be members of the Board of
Directors of the League, many of
whom are Hopkins alumni; the
presidents of all the colleges in the
State; the presidents of the various
boards of trade in the city, and
many other leading Marylanders.
The same band which furnished the
music at President Goodnow's inauguration has been secured.
The meeting will be preceded by
a mammoth parade, in which fourteen organizations have already signified their intention to participate.
Among these are the Boy Scouts
and the Fourth and Fifth Regiments. It is hoped that the First
Regiment, which is composed of
,var.ious 'companies all over the
State, will, also be on hand. An
effort is being made to procure a
detachment of regulars. This parade will be the first big demonstration held in this State in behalf
of national defense.

By GEO. EDWIN DORSEY

The magnificent victory of the
football team on Thanksgiving
Day, which sent what was perhaps
the most formidable aggregation
that has ever represented any college in Maryland down to defeat
and at last gave to Johns Hopkins
the premier position in the State
in football that it has held in the
other branches of sport for some
time, completed what was probably
the most crucial year of football
that the University has ever had.
While it is always thought at the
time that every year is crucial in
football, a moment's consideration
will show in how many respects
1915 was especially so for Johns
Hopkins. At the conclusion of the
1914 season the team had won two
games, tied one and lost five. The
defeats all came in a row, with
the exception of the tie with Gettysburg. .In addition, one of the players was so severely injured in one
of the games that he died later.
The crowds on the whole were fair,
considering the performance of the
team. But after that deadly St.
John's affair, when, before next
to the largest crowd that has ever
seen a Hopkins-St. John's game,
the team was defeated 34 to 13,
there was a general feeling of peSsimism regarding football possibilities at the University, and the public was disgusted.
It made no difference when we
pleaded that laboratories made it
practically impossible for the team
to get any daylight practice; that
for two weeks before the biggest
game of the year no forward passes
could be attempted on account of
the ball's passing out of the zone
of the acetylene lights; that we had
no larger a student body to draw
from than several of the other colleges in the State, which were not
hampered for time to practice. We
simply had a consistently-losing
football team, and hence any pretensions of the University in this field
were a joke.
Keenly cognizant of all this, a
number of the alumni and members of the Athletic Board had a
meeting to face the facts. Alost of
these (myself among the number)
were in favor of either abolishing
football altogether or of removing
the almost insuperable obstacles
which were in the way of our turning out creditable football teams.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 29, 1915.

DEBATERS PICK OUT SUBJECTS CHAUCERIAN LECTURES ISSUED COTILLON SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED
Topics for Argument in Triangular League
Selected—New System Proposed by
North Carolina Rejected.

At a meeting of the Debating
Council. last Wednesday a request
of the University of North Caroline to alter the system of the triangular league was considered and
.reliised, and the ,choice of a subject to submit to the other two
members -of the league was undertaken.
The request of the University of
North Carolina was that the system of debate under which Virginia, North Carolina and Hopkins
have held their debates in the past
be so altered that instead of both of
the teams of each university debating away from home, one team of
each university should meet its opponent upon its home ground.
The Council was taken somewhat
unawares by this request, as there
had been no inkling of it before the
letter sent by North Carolina was
received, and as the system in the
past had been considered to work
with remarkable success. The proposed change was taken up as the
first business of the meeting, and,
after some discussion, it was decided that a letter should be sent
to the University of North Carolina stating that Hopkins preferred
debating under the old arrangements.
The Council, in taking this action, decided that whatever might
be the advantages of one team debating at its own university, the
present system, under which- each
team debates in foreign territory,
has proved to be so exceedingly
satisfactory that it should not be
superseded. Under the present system, the conditions under which the
teams debate are made as equal as
is possible, while under the proposed system one team would always have the advantages of familiarity. with the surroundings and the
support of the audience. The debates of the past have always drawn
large crowds, even though the local
university was not represented, and
the ,system itself has been thought
to be so successful as to be given
in full in the last Inter-collegiate
Debate Book.
After action had been taken upon
this matter, the subject which Hopkins is to propose to the other two
members of the league was considered. The committee appointed
to submit a list of subjects, consisting of A. A. Weech (chairman), T.
J. Tingley and R. Oppenheimer,
made a report prdposing about
eight subjects for consideration by
the Council. After some discussion, these subjects were narrowed
down to three: The unicameral system in State governments, the State
budget, and the advisability of the
annexation of Nicaragua by the
United States.
These subjects have not as yet
been definitely worded, and it is
indeed possible that none of them

Series Given by Professor Kittredge at
Hopkins Done into Book Form—Author Thanks Johns Hopkins
for Co-operation.

The six lectures delivered upon
Chaucer by Prof. George L. Kittredge, of Harvard University, at
Johns Hopkins in 1914, as the
Turnbull lectures of that year, have
been published in book form.
As will be remembered, this series
of lectures was, at the time, considered one of the best ever given under the Foundation. Professor Kittredge is one of the best Chaucerian
authorities in the country, and the
publication of these lectures have
been looked forward to with much
interest by all Chaucerian scholars.
The lectures have been transposed
to book form with very few
changes. The introduction of the
book reads as follows:
"The six lectures that comprise
this volume were delivered at the
Johns Hopkins University in April
and May, 1914, being the nineteenth course of lectures in poetry
in the Percy Turnbull Memorial
Foundation. They are presented as
delivered, except with such slight
emendations as naturally suggest
themselves when one prepares a
manuscript for the press. Since
the plan of the book excludes footnotes, I wish to make the fullest
kind of general acknowledgement
to Chaucerian scholars in both hemispheres for the help which their
published writings have afforded
me. To the founders of the lectureship and to my friends and colleagues in Baltimore, I am deeply
indebted for their cordial expressions of interest and their delightful
hospitality.
"Cambridge, January 22, 1915."
The lectures are arranged in the
book in the exact order in which
they were delivered at Hopkins:
First, there is "The Man and His
Times"; second, "The Book of the
Duchess"; third, "The House of
Fame"; fourth, "Troilus"; fifth,
"The Canterbury Tales"(part one);
and sixth, "The Canterbury Tales"
(part two).
Professor Kittredge has been in
Baltimore several times since he delivered his lectures, several of his
friends being members of the Hopkins faculty. His last public apnearance before the University was
at the inauguration ceremonies last
May, when he was awarded an
honorary degree.

First Dance to Take Place December 4.
Music by Fisher's Orchestra—Expected to Be Great Success.

Friday evening, December 3, will
mark the opening of the Cotillon
Club's activities. A large majority
of the undergraduates, graduates
and alumni are expected to attend
this, the first Hopkins dance of the
season; and the Cotillon Board
hopes this dance will excel all previous ones in attendance and enjoyment.
As in former years, Louie Fisher
will have charge of the music, and
from the time he starts to play for
the first dance at 9 o'clock sharp
until the end, the dancers will have
the benefit of as fine dance music
as can be heard anywhere in the
United States. There will be an intermission at i i o'clock for refreshments, after which the dance will
continue until 12.30.
The Cotillon Board has announced its plans for the rest of
the scholastic year. There will be
a second dance On the evening of
February 4, and the last (lance of
the year will take place on April 29.
The dance is open to the whole
University—graduates, undergraduates, and alumni—and the members of the faculty and their wives
are cordially invited by the Cotillon
Club to be present.
Among those who have been
asked to act as chaperons for the
occasion are the following: Mrs. J.
E. Gilpin, Mrs. F. J. Goodnow,
Mrs. M. P. Brush, Mrs. B. H. Griswold, Jr. Mrs. J. M. Vincent, Mrs.
Caswell '
Grave, Mrs. Watson and
Mrs. Henry Wood.
The treasurer of the Cotillon
Board is very anxious to have
everyone pay up as soon as possible.
There is a charge of $2.50 for undergraduates and graduates for
one cotillon, or $6 for the series of
three dances. The charge for alumni is $1.5o for one dance, or $4 for
the three.
The Cotillon Board, in whose
hands rests the arrangement of all
affairs connected with the dances, is
composed of the following: Charles
H. Tinges, chairman; William H.
Skinner, secretary; Robert G.. Merrick, treasurer; Franklin Cromwell,
Stuart Egerton, A. A. Hardy, William Kendall, Jr., R. W. Woodward.

The annual freshman-sophomore
football game is scheduled to take
place on the afternoon of Saturday,
December 4. This will be the first
direct clash in which the two underclasses will have engaged, and the
outcome of the contest will play a
large part in forming opinion as to
the relative strength of the two
classes.
Although Coach Brickley has
been asked to coach the freshmen,
according to his announcement at
the last mass-meeting he will help
both teams, devoting the most of
his time to whichever team is the
weakest.
Both sophomores and freshmen
have men on the 'Varsity and both
also have a large number of men on
the "scrubs." Hoffman, of course,
is the most prominent man in the
sophomore line-up, but there will
also be Woodward, Cort, Duncan
and Darley, who have been practicing with the 'Varsity the entire
season.
Schmidt is the only freshman
who has played on the first team
throughout the season. However,
Sonneborn, Frock, Stanley, Kirke
and Prince, all members of the Hopkins squad, are all freshmen and
are expected to form the nucleus
of an extremely good team. Moreover, there are several good players
in the Freshman Class who did not
go out for the Hopkins team.
Among these are Allen and Cox,
who played on the City College
eleven last year, and Frisch and
Myer, who played backfield positions for Friends' School.
The freshman team began practice Saturday, November 27. Although many sophomores have been
practicing with the 'Varsity squad,
the regular practice of the lophomore team did not begin until Monday of this week.

pleasure in announcing the election
to the editorial staff of Henry C.

The State Championship.

When the football team began
practice upon Homewood Field this
September, they went out with a
definite aim. It was an aim which
-has been held by every one of Hopkins' football teams for the last
decade—the winning of the championship of the State. As the season progressed, and as one victory
after the other was brought home
under the guidance of Coaches
Brickley and Brennick, the hopes
of the University mounted higher
and higher, until, before the St.
John's game, they welt aroused
to fever pitch. Our team realized what the winning of those
last two games meant, and it went
into them with a spirit which has
never been excelled in the history
of Hopkins. With the blowing of
the final whistle last Thursday, that
spirit had proven its power—the
long-coveted championship had been
attained.
That last victory was one of
which the University may well be
proud. Won •over a team which
contested every inch of ground and
which fought as clean and as
straight a game as it is possible to
fight, -it means that our success

is flawless; that, in fact as well as
in title, our team is the best within
the State.
Coming at a time when the longcherished dream of moving to
Homewood is about to be realized,
our victory has a double significance. It not only means that the
team of this year is the champion
of the State; it means also that
Hopkins has now a record to maintain and a reputation up to which
to live.
The crowd which thronged the
stands and field last Thursday is
proof of the increased importance
which is being attached to the contests of the Hopkins team; it is for
us to prove that the team which
won this support is only to be the
forerunner of a long line of teams
which will uphold the standard it
has set.
We cannot place our hopes too
high; it would be useless to predict
that within the next few years Hopkins will have a team which will
rival those of universities with five
and six thousand students. Yet
this much we can say: the team and
the spirit which this season has produced are not a culmination, but a
beginning.
Brickley.

Hopkins is tasting the sweets of
victory, and, in enjoying that victory, it remembers and thanks the
men who made it possible. We owe
the football championship of the
State to the men of the team, to
their fighting spirit, destined to live
long in Hopkins history; we owe it
to the "scrubs" who have given
their best in obscurity that the team
might be the stronger; but, more
than to anyone else, we owe it to one
man—Charles Brickley.
Brickley came to this University
fresh from the laurels of national
honors; he came from a university
twenty times as large as Hopkins,
from a team which was one of the
best that university ever produced.
He came to a university whose
spirit suffered from the undeniable
handicap of the lack of dormitories,
a university where the total number of candidates was not onethird as large as the "scrub" forces
of his old team. Yet, despite these
things, he threw himself into his
work with all the enthusiasm of
which he was capable; he devoted
all of his time and energy to the
building up of a team that has
gloriously proved its worth, and
to the development of a spirit which
marks the beginning of a new University.
He has done more than give
Hopkins a championship team. He
has been more than a coach, and
has done, more than merely fulfill
the requirements of his position. In
every sense of the word, he has
been a Hopkins man.
,THE NEWS-LETTER desires to express its most Sincere hope that
Brickley will be back again next
year to lead our team once more to
triumphant victory. But, whether
'he be here or not, there is not a
man in the University who does

not appreciate the great benefits
which his presence has brought, and
who does not feel personally grateful for what he has done.
BRICKLEY'S ACHIEVEMENT A
RECORD IN HOPKINS FOOTBALL
(Continued from page I)

situation was enlisted and permission was finally given that the men
who were playing football would
be allowed to leave the laboratories
at from 3.30 to 4 o'clock, and these
men would be given every chance
possible to make up their work.
This was not, however, accomplished as easily as it sounds, and it
was only after the faculty saw that
something must be done, that they
were won,over.
With a vague promise that this
might be accomplished, the work
of selecting the coach was undertaken. There were a number of
possibilities, but, of course, out-topping all the rest was Charlie Brickley. It is no betrayal of confidence
to say that he was an expensive
proposition for Johns Hopkins, and
we should not have been able to
secure his services had not the
alumni stepped into the breach and
said that, with the belief that the
faculty would cooperate, to some
extent at least, they would supply
the necessary help.
Under these circumstances Brickley was brought to Hopkins. He
came to us as probably the most
famous college man in America,
having had all of the honors that
could be given him on the football
field, on the baseball field, as a
member of the United States Olympic team, etc. He had everything
to lose, and what looked at the time
like very little to gain, by coming
to Hopkins. He had received letters from former Hopkins football
coaches, telling him what he was
up against at Hopkins. But he
nevertheless decided to come. Had
he not been any more successful
than those who had gone before,
the difficulties at Hopkins would
have received wide-spread notoriety
because of Brickley's fame. Thus
we, in a way, were risking a lot
by bringing a man with Brickley's
reputation to Hopkins. But those
who were responsible for the thing
were confident that it would at least
bring matters to a head—it would
either work or it would be the
reductio ad absurdum,.
And those who would have had
to have borne the brunt of the
whole affair felt more than repaid
when the referee's whistle blew on
Thanksgiving Day and those eleven
tired but victorious men trotted off
They were
Homewood Field.
moved by a feeling of profound
gratification, for they had seen what
Hopkins could do if it got a chance,
and had had the faith, which even
some loyal Hopkins men had lost,
rewarded.
Thus the 1915 football situation
was crucial in that it was a case of
either kill or cure. And, in a way,
it is especially gratifying to all

Hopkins men that the team should
have done so well in 1915, for this
is almost certainly the last year of
the old conditions. With every indication that the University, in all
its branches, will be at Homewood
next year, with entirely new conditions, it was our last chance to
show these, as it seemed at times,
hypercritical Baltimoreans a n d
Marylanders what Johns Hopkins
could do when it got the opportunity. And even the most skeptical were silent after that Thanksgiving Day set-to.
From the above, it is seen that it
is impossible to attribute to any
one source the success of the team.
The faculty perhaps did the most,
theoretically; but, practically, the
men did not get out the way it had
been hoped they would. They had
a most exasperating habit, from
the coaches' standpoint, of being
detained by some long experiment,
and of not getting on the field until
after dark.
And had it not been for the undying determination in the hearts
of men like Brooks, Hoffman, Wilkinson, Leibensperger, Bowers,
Primrose, Fulton, Gorman and the
many others on the squad to wipe
out the old stigma on Hopkins football, and the faithful interest of
Ormond, Barclay, Finney, Martindale and Sachs, who had other alma
maters, no amount of getting out
early or of superior coaching would
have availed, and the closing season
woultd have had a very different
story to tell. One of the characteristics of the team most commented on was its fight and the grim
determination which often turned
what looked like defeat into ultimate victory.
But, without taking any of the
credit from the faculty, or forgetting that it was the fight of the
men which made victory possible, it
is Charlie Brickley, more than any
other one person, who must be
given the credit for achieving the
1915 success. And it must be said
that he had been receiving the
credit that is due him from the
public and students alike, which is
why I mentioned the two other
factors, which are likely to be overlooked in the universal rejoicing.
However, these do not in any way
mar the splendor of the Hopkins
"miracle man."
When he first came to Baltimore
and fully realized what he was up
against, Brickley was profoundly
discouraged. And it was here that
Hank Brennick got in his fine work,
for he took Charlie in hand, and
with a skill rarely equaled led him
out of the "chaos," to use Brickley's own term, in which he found
himself shortly after assuming
charge of the squad. But once
having gotten his feet, there was
no stopping him. He worked
among the medical men and undergraduates alike, and not only did
he get them out, but he kept them
out, which is most important of
all. Never in my experience with
Hopkins' teams has a coach had

McCOY HALL CONCERT FEB. 25
Musicians to Hold Home Engagement at
Favorable Time—Men Still Needed
for Both Clubs—Prospects Bright.

The Musical Clubs are now in
full swing, and, from the progress
thus far made, there is every prospect that the season will be as successful as that of any of the Clubs
of previous years.
An unusually large number of
candidates has reported at the Glee
Club rehearsals, and, while it is still
too early to choose the men who are
to have places in the Club, with the
material on hand there should be no
,difficulty in finding enough good
singers for every part. The competition, however, is just beginning
and all candidates who have not yet
registered are urged to do so as
soon as possible.
The old members of the Glee
Club have turned out in full force
and furnish a nucleus around which
the Club is easily reshaping itself.
In addition, several good voices
have been found in the Freshman
Class. The chief difficulty which
confronts the Club is the same difficulty against Which it has been
necessary for all Hopkins clubs to
contend—the majority of the men
are unable to read music, and must
be taught their parts separately.
However, this difficulty can be overcome by patient practice, and every
week, as the men become more fathiliar with the music, better results
are being obtained.
The Glee Club now meets twice
a week—on Tuesday evenings and
on Saturday afternoons. Likewise,
as the season progresses, rehearsals
at the lunch hour will be begun.
This frequent and regular practice
for the Glee Club is comparatively
a new thing at Hopkins, and is already showing results.
The Instrumental Club, while
progressing satisfactorily, is still in
need of men. There is room in
every department of the orchestra
—piano, violins, mandolins, guitars,
'cello, bass-violin, flute and drums.
The Club lost several valuable members last year, and still others, due
to sickness or work, have so far
found it impossible to report at the
rehearsals.
Despite this handicap, however,
the Club is gradually rounding into
shape. The rehearsals take place
Friday evening, as is the custom of
this Club. Due to the failure of the
publishers to send the music which
had been ordered, rehearsals were
begun somewhat later this year than
is usual, but the spirit which all the
men are putting into their practice
has more than made up for the late
start.
While no trips have as yet been
arranged, the managerial staff announces that several are under consideration, and that the season as a
whole is expected to be a busy one.
The McCoy Hall concert has been
booked for February 25, this date
having been temporarily selected so
as not to conflict with the cotillons
or any other University activity.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 29, 1915.
Hopkins Men Will Usher.

A letter has been received from
the Maryland League for National
Defense, asking for twenty-five
Hopkins men to serve as ushers at
the big mass-meeting for national
defense at the Lyric on Saturday,
December 4. Seniors.are preferred,
but it makes little difference, so king
as they are Hopkins men. Each
usher will be given two reserVed
seats.
It is expected that the ushers will
have their "hands full," for the
Lyric will be filled to its maximum
capacity. The principal speaker of
the evening will be the Hon. James
M. Beck, of New York, who is
considered the country's greatest
orator on national defense. The
vice-presidents of the mass-meeting
will be members of the Board of
Directors of the League, many of
whom are Hopkins alumni; the
presidents of all the colleges in the
State; the presidents of the various
boards of trade in the city, and
many other leading Marylanders.
The same band which furnished the
music at President Goodnow's inauguration has been secured.
The meeting will be preceded by
a mammoth parade, in which fourteen organizations have already signified their intention to participate.
Among these are the Boy Scouts
and the Fourth and Fifth Regiments. It is hoped that the First
